rev.comment: /* Censorship in mainland China */ everybody is blocked, no matter citizens or not

Line 161: Line 161:
[[Image:Google-censorship-slips.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Two "sensitive" images slip through the net on Page 5 of the Image Search results of "Tiananmen" on Google China (February 15, 2006)]]
[[Image:Google-censorship-slips.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Two "sensitive" images slip through the net on Page 5 of the Image Search results of "Tiananmen" on Google China (February 15, 2006)]]
â
The [[People's Republic of China]] (PRC), whose [[human rights in the People's Republic of China|human rights record]] has been widely criticized by the international community, has in the past [[Internet censorship in mainland China|restricted citizen access]] to popular search engines such as [[Altavista]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[Google (search engine)|Google]]. The mirror search site [[elgooG]] has been used by its citizens in [[mainland China]] to get around blocked content. This complete ban is currently lifted. However, the government remains active in filtering Internet content. In October 2005, Blogger and access to the Google Cache were made available in mainland China; however, in December 2005, some mainland Chinese users of Blogger reported that their access to the site was once again restricted.
+
The [[People's Republic of China]] (PRC), whose [[human rights in the People's Republic of China|human rights record]] has been widely criticized by the international community, has in the past [[Internet censorship in mainland China|restricted citizen access]] to popular search engines such as [[Altavista]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[Google (search engine)|Google]]. The mirror search site [[elgooG]] has been used by users in [[mainland China]] to get around blocked content. This complete ban is currently lifted. However, the government remains active in filtering Internet content. In October 2005, Blogger and access to the Google Cache were made available in mainland China; however, in December 2005, some mainland Chinese users of Blogger reported that their access to the site was once again restricted.
In January 2006 Google affirmed its intent to filter certain keywords given to it by the government of the PRC. The restrictions will apply to thousands of terms and websites.[http://www.breitbart.com/news/2006/01/24/D8FBCF686.html] The censored content will appear on a website called google.cn. Google was heavily criticized for the move, yet it claims it is necessary to keep the PRC government from blocking Google entirely. The company does not plan to give the government information about the users who search for blocked content, and will inform users of restricted categories. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4647398.stm] Google states on its help pages that it does not censor content, but it does block pages as demanded for in certain jurisdictions, such as [[DMCA]] requests in the United States.
In January 2006 Google affirmed its intent to filter certain keywords given to it by the government of the PRC. The restrictions will apply to thousands of terms and websites.[http://www.breitbart.com/news/2006/01/24/D8FBCF686.html] The censored content will appear on a website called google.cn. Google was heavily criticized for the move, yet it claims it is necessary to keep the PRC government from blocking Google entirely. The company does not plan to give the government information about the users who search for blocked content, and will inform users of restricted categories. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4647398.stm] Google states on its help pages that it does not censor content, but it does block pages as demanded for in certain jurisdictions, such as [[DMCA]] requests in the United States.
